The Board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted unanimously today to endorse Los Angeles mayor Antonio Villaraigosa's proposal to build 12 Measure R mass transit projects in ten years, instead of the original 30. The proposal was even amended to include other transportation projects benefiting the county. Among these projects are an extension of the Metro Orange Line past Canoga, and a much-needed extension IMO of the subway from Downtown to the Westside.

If you're wondering why it took so long for a Westside rail line, well... you're only half right. 

While browsing through blogdowntown.com, I discovered yesterday was the 66th anniversary of the "Four Level" interchange’s unveiling in downtown Los Angeles. The four-level, for my non-Angeleno readers, is the notorious traffic pit where Highway 101 and the 110 Freeway meet. 

But that same year -- 1944 -- ridership hit an all-time high on the old Pacific Electric Railway. The Pacific Electric whatsit? Yes, there was a time when all of the Southland, reaching as far as Santa Ana, was connected by lines of electric streetcar tracks. Just like in San Francisco. In fact, beginning a hundred years ago, the "Balloon Route" on the PER ran from Downtown through Hollywood, Santa Monica, Venice Beach, Redondo Beach and back to L.A. via Culver City.

You heard right: An electric streetcar line once connected Hollywood, Downtown and the Westside, in one fell swoop.

Here's a broader map from around 1910, courtesy of the University of Southern California archives:



See? Light rail is nothing new. On a side note, I like how under this old infrastructure, I could have ridden a streetcar from my old apartment in mid-Wilshire to my Disney job in Glendale, nine miles away.

So what happened? Ironically, electric streetcars were already old news by 1944. As early as the 1920s, certain routes were phasing out to make room for buslines and paved roads. Trains had to yield high speed right of ways to traffic crossings. In the LA before freeways, mass transit was -- irony of ironies -- an increasing inconvenience, a pothole in the road of progress. After all, why bother with rail schedules when you have the personal freedom of an automobile? Indeed, gas was cheap, the LA Basin is flat... and if you think about it, cars were just beginning to be marketed the right way. Another side note: Why aren't car ads that poetic anymore? 

And so, proposals for a subway and elevated rail system were defeated, and priorities shifted to car travel. You probably don’t go through the day thinking about highway designs, but just to put things in perspective, the four-level was absolute state of the art engineering. Unlike earlier cloverleaf designs, it avoided conflict between entering and exiting traffic by providing distinct ramps between all travel options. My old friend, the Los Angeles Times loved it, of course. When construction began in 1947, a rendering of the interchange made the front page. The paper described the interchange as, "One of the most intricate projects in the history of roadbuilding (1947)," and "…the fanciest whip-de-do of bridges, curving ramps and sweeping underpasses that you ever saw (18 July, 1949)."

The interchange finally opened for traffic in 1953. Eight years later, a lack of public funding closed the railways for good. 

And now, on the week of the interchange's anniversary, Villaraigosa is overheard discussing with a visiting President Obama about federal funding to hasten the development of… a rail line connecting Downtown to the westside. The 101/110 interchange is among the most congested in the United States. In fact, of the ten worst highway bottlenecks nationally, four belong to Los Angeles. Naturally, the four-level structure is now named after Bill Keene -- a traffic reporter. 

Irony aside, however, I'm happy the 30/10 initiative garnered more support today. What I want to know is, would ridership still have peaked in 1944 without wartime gasoline rationing? 

Happy Earth Day!

I was never a big fan of Irvine. I only moved here because the job I wanted was in Irvine. Funnily enough, after living here for six months, I think I’ve been approaching the city from the wrong angle.

Let’s say you woke up tomorrow morning and discovered your car was replaced with a bright red, mint condition, 1967 Alfa Romeo Spider Duetto. No strings attached. Tempting, but then the right side of your brain kicks in. This car is noisy, uncomfortable, lacks room for more than two people and lacks space for more than two bags. You’d get to drive it maybe once a month, and spend the rest of your time figuring out the new reason why it won’t start.

But my God, those curves, the open top, that throaty exhaust… marrone! The Duetto is a sexy little minx, ain’t it? The car possesses that mystical variable all automakers covet: character. As any classic sports car enthusiast knows, the repairs and the impracticalities of their rides are part of what constitutes “character.” Maintaining the car is what intimately bonds driver and machine. It helps Nigel Shiftright better appreciate the car’s more alluring assets.

Going back to the Southland, I lived in the Larchmont (mid-Wilshire) district of Los Angeles for most of last year. In concept, Larchmont Village offers just about everything I ever wanted from a home at that time. I was a few miles from any part of the city, including the Westside, Hollywood or the hip bohemianism of Los Feliz and Silverlake. The Larchmont farmer’s market was even walking distance from my apartment.

But soon reality weighed down on me like the blanket of smog ever-lingering over Downtown. Yes, everything is a few miles away, but getting there means sitting in incessant freeway traffic or battling through endless stoplights on crowded, cramped city streets. What about light rail? Well, Metro works great… as long as your destination is anywhere but where Metro’s arguably needed most: Downtown-Westside and especially Valley-Westside. The weather is almost as hot in the summer as the Valley, and the air quality is even worse. A tony English manor in Windsor Square may lie a block away from a slum on the outskirts of Koreatown.

Such quirks are part of living in a big city like Los Angeles. Urban commandos argue that it’s up to us to improve the neighborhoods and make them better places to live. This is how gentrification projects get started in eastside neighborhoods like Silverlake, Echo Park and Eagle Rock. Even Culver City on the Westside used to be rundown. Ah, but Los Angeles, you see, exudes “character” in a way none of the cities in south Orange County could understand. It has spirit, verve, charisma — whatever you want to call it. It’s a fixer-upper of a town with mountains, beaches, nightlife, daylife and everything in between.

Wait, so LA is fun because it’s high maintenance? Well, I think humans of a certain age and lifestyle are drawn to the risk and character of urban life, just as one feels drawn towards an Italian sports car. We like fixing up Echo Park because the neighborhood feels “authentic” and “dangerous” — but not quite Pico-Union dangerous, naturally. Just dangerous enough so residents can make fun of people from the Valley or OC for being “soft.”

This is one of the reasons Irvine is anathema to the average LA hipster. The way I see it, though, Irvine is boring the way a Camry is boring. Everything works the way it’s supposed to work, right out of the box. Low crime, lots of parking, good air quality, great schools, easy access to freeways and the beach… are these really such bad things? Am I soft? I don’t see why. At this point in my life, I’d rather live in a city that works. I appreciate how much the Irvine Company cares about creating a livable environment.

Don’t get me wrong, I love LA’s finer qualities. I have nothing but respect for urban activists. If I want to experience some character, though, then LA will be waiting for me on the weekend.

Besides: Don’t people normally purchase Alfa-Romeos as second cars?

Wow, I really need to update this more. Now I have to catch you up on what happened at the Game Developers Conference last week. No Double Fine or Bioware at the Career Pavilion this year -- BUT... there was a company I admire maybe only 5% less than Double Fine: Telltale Games. I like to think of Telltale as what LucasArts was like 15 or 20 years ago -- a lot of old-school adventure games with some great jokes. Which figures, since most of the staff used to work there. The Lead Designer, for example, is Dave Grossman, who co-designed Day of the Tentacle. Anyway... I saw Telltale was hiring interns AND testers, so I knew I had to make my move. I made a couple of jokes with the people at the booth, and finagled my way into a promise of facetime with Grossman the following day. Okay, that's a start. I return the next day. Dave is eating lunch at the back of the booth. It's kinda surreal to see one of your gaming heroes eating lunch... but I digress. I come back fifteen minutes later. The people at the booth recognize me from yesterday, and there I am, talking to Dave Grossman. Nice. I tell him I've been a fan since DoTT. "Wow! How old you were back then?" Seven, for the record. I didn't discover these games until a little bit after Grim Fandango was released. I tell him I'm a writer, I can do this and that, and what should I do if I want a chance with you guys. He says to send him some writing samples. Alright, sure. I give him a business card for good measure.  So that was last Thursday. I started compiling together things to send him on Saturday, but it took me until this afternoon to send him the e-mail because I kept checking to see whether any of Project Mean One was worthy of sending (it wasn't). I ended up giving him three Nexus columns, the module I made for Bioware last year, my resume and much worry on my part he wouldn't be able to open the module. For that matter, will he respond? That agent Kate referred me to never did. Not only did he respond, but it was only an hour after I sent the e-mail. Not only that, his first sentence is that my business card is sitting on his desk. BUT... --Can't open the module (I knew it!) --Says my columns "aren't bad" --Says Telltale's not hiring for writing/design interns. I remember him saying that last part at the show, but he said to send him stuff anyway. But then he said I had "interesting stuff" on my resume, which he then delivered by hand to the guy looking at the QA resumes. Your guess is as good as mine what happens from here. My "let's be realistic" guess is I can maybe score a phone interview. It had better not be in person because, by the way, Telltale is based in San Rafael. That's 385 miles away...

Let me preface this post by saying that I didn't intend to move out of Tarzana any earlier than December. I even wanted to wait until January. But then Soo text messages me Sunday morning and says there's a studio apartment available in her complex for $650 a month. Preposterous, I thought. -- she had to have meant $950. Even Van Nuys barely has studios for $950. No, she says, it's $650. Her mom is friends with the landlord. Now Soo does not live in the Valley. She actually lives down in Mid-Wilshire, near Larchmont Village. The nearest cross street is Melrose and Clifton. A Google Maps search revealed that her place is only 9 miles from work, so I bit and told her I was interested. Since then, I've driven down to check out the apartment and neighborhood, and discovered to my surprise that Larchmont is really handy. It's walking distance from Hollywood Forever Cemetery (where Cinespia is held in the summer), and also from freaking Paramount Studios -- where I would work if I got the transcriber job with Dr. Phil that I applied to on a lark last week. Pink's? 2 miles. The Grove? 2.7 miles. Fox? 7.5 miles. Activision/Square Enix? Well, an hour with traffic. That's better than the 90 minutes it takes currently. The month-to-month lease would allow me to look for a place in the South Bay if the need should arise. The drive to Alex's is now 42 miles, which is the primary downside. Better than the 60-odd miles it took from Goleta, but still a pain. But still, this bears repeating: My VERY OWN studio apartment -- not a rented room -- in Larchmont Village, for $650 a month. This is not a big deal in Atlanta dollars, but friggin' amazing here. Anyway, Soo said the place is mine by virtue of us being friends, so I don't have to worry about competition. After much research and inspection, I decided to go for it. Move-in will be November 16.
